answers.answer: Excerpt from Life Extension - Thyroid Regulation..."According to a study reported in Lancet, various TSH levels that fall within normal range are associated with adverse health outcomes.26TSH greater than 2.0: increased 20-year risk of hypothyroidism and increased risk of thyroid autoimmune diseaseTSH between 2.0 and 4.0: hypercholesterolemia and cholesterol levels decline in response to T4 therapyTSH greater than 4.0: greater risk of heart disease"

A lot of doctors aren't willing to treat until labs are well out of range and symptoms are raging, or they want people to wait six months before retesting.  So, your doctor's approach seems reasonable, relatively speaking.  Perhaps you could ask him to shorten the time period a little to the next test?When you're tested again, be sure that your doctor orders FREE T3 (FT3) and FREE T4 (FT4) along with TSH.  FT3 and FT4 are the actual thyroid hormones and give a much better picture of thyroid status.  You want to be about mid-range on both, but we can help you interpret the tests if you post results with reference ranges. Reference ranges vary lab to lab, so they have to come from your own lab report.By far, autoimmune thyroid disease is the leading cause of hypothyroidism.  The two markers for Hashimoto's thyroiditis are TPOab (thyroid peroxidase antibodies) and TGab (thyroglobulin antibodies).  It would be well worthwhile to have those tested at the same time.
